text: Evening Briefing: Here's what you need to know at the end of the day. https://t.co/NCok7G7onY

name: nytimes
text:
RT @jmartNYT: NEW:  Marc Racicot, the former MT governor & RNC chair, tells us why he decided to go public for Biden.

“It gnawed at my conscience,” he said, adding of Trump: “I’ve concluded that he’s dangerous to the existence of the republic as we know it.”

https://t.co/dV967BScrV

name: nytimes
text: Joe Biden embarked on his most vigorous day of campaigning in months on Wednesday, setting off on an old-fashioned train tour to directly appeal to the blue-collar white Americans who powered Donald Trump’s victories in the Midwest in 2016. https://t.co/aOVyD1FQ4A

name: nytimes
text: RT @matthewhaag: I visited Jackson Heights in Queens today on the first day of indoor dining. Restaurant owners were excited, but many customers were hesitant to eat inside.  https://t.co/0ceTVgxf6M

name: nytimes
text:
In Opinion

Our columnist @fmanjoo tracked President Trump’s statements on masks to see how he helped turn them into a cultural flash point. “What we’ve come up with is an illustration of a tremendous missed opportunity,” Manjoo writes. https://t.co/CoQPyWOuvm

name: nytimes
text: The former FBI director James Comey, testifying before the Senate Judiciary Committee on Wednesday, defended the Trump-Russia investigation as Republicans again sought to cast doubt on the inquiry before Election Day. https://t.co/AItiNpvyN9

text: RT @koblin: The viewership totals were also surprisingly steady throughout the debate. On the top 7 networks, peak audience was between 9:30 and 9:45. Only modest declines after that. https://t.co/DbkwQtluSY https://t.co/6pAlsx2WyF

text:

https://t.co/yl44VeT8v6

text: Stock trading in the world’s third-largest economy ground to a near standstill on Thursday morning after a technical glitch shut down the Tokyo Stock Exchange and some other markets across Japan. https://t.co/FgfGtIoalg

name: nytimes
text: The World Health Organization has long encouraged mass tourism and said closing borders wouldn’t stop the spread of Covid-19. A New York Times investigation found this policy was never based on science, but instead on politics and economics. https://t.co/vkriomgxhY

nytimes
text: By introducing a new color called "period red," the color registry company Pantone aims to make all people, whether they menstruate or not, "feel comfortable to talk spontaneously and openly about this pure and natural bodily function.” https://t.co/oc1NwRLYss

name: nytimes
text: Even during the 1918 Spanish flu pandemic and both World Wars, Rio de Janeiro’s famous carnival went on with the show. But the coronavirus has forced an indefinite suspension of the parade, leaving the city reeling. https://t.co/h3MgvRatbM

name: nytimes
text: The coronavirus has hit the most economically vulnerable districts of Madrid disproportionately hard, leaving poorer residents of the Spanish capital under renewed lockdown measures while people in more affluent areas can move freely. https://t.co/b0USZ7AIZM

name: nytimes
text: When the ferry the Estonia sank off Finland in 1994, killing 852 people, investigators said a bow door had been bashed in by heavy seas. But a new documentary raises fresh details that point to a far darker conclusion. https://t.co/Jk7Tx4iHXN

name: nytimes
text: RT @nytclimate: In the first presidential debate, when Joe Biden said Donald Trump has relaxed regulations regarding methane emissions, the President shook his head and responded, "Not true." But our running tally of environmental rollbacks includes several methane rules. https://t.co/aq0mZMRLJJ

name: nytimes
text: A new show dramatizes the 2018 poisoning of a former Russian spy in the English city of Salisbury. Even for a reporter who covered the real events, the four episodes contain revelations. https://t.co/kjnB60zj9v

name: nytimes
text:
“Driving home from the hospital with no baby,” Chrissy Teigen wrote on Twitter. “How can this be real.”

She said she and her husband, John Legend, had decided to call their son Jack. https://t.co/Tj73olAWJ4

name: nytimes
text: Aleksei Navalny, who was poisoned in August in Siberia, said in an interview with Der Spiegel that he has no doubt that President Vladimir Putin was behind the attack. https://t.co/hg8pggHQDf

name: nytimes
text: A teenager from an Indian village who was raped by a group of men died of her injuries at a hospital in New Delhi, triggering widespread outrage again after years of what experts describe as a gang rape epidemic in India. https://t.co/8HyDCOE9lu

name: nytimes
text: The European Commission announced that it was pressing ahead with legal action against Britain over Brexit legislation that the government in London has said would permit it to break international law. https://t.co/Ar1xynInCo

name: nytimes
text:
Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand said she had used cannabis “a long time ago.” 

But she stopped short of backing legalization in a referendum this month. https://t.co/SSH8vXELKy

name: nytimes
text: New York City is reopening all its public schools in a milestone for the city’s recovery from its position as the global epicenter of the coronavirus pandemic. https://t.co/OQq6KsqPDn

name: nytimes
text: Despite a fast-growing number of coronavirus cases, India will allow cinemas and entertainment parks to open with limited capacity beginning October 15. https://t.co/CNNWKKJjh9

name: nytimes
text: The U.S. Army released new guidelines for optimal soldier performance — and they include strategic and aggressive napping. https://t.co/r0wPSbVd1b

name: nytimes
text: Turkey has acknowledged that it was not making all confirmed coronavirus cases public in its daily announced tally. It was counting only patients showing symptoms. https://t.co/mJBSU0qLN9

name: nytimes
text:
China has kicked off Golden Week, the annual spree of shopping and travel built around the October 1 National Day celebrations. 

It's the first major holiday since the country brought its coronavirus epidemic more or less under control. https://t.co/Iflw4mHAp7

name: nytimes
text: "Joe Biden cast the first presidential debate as a leadership test for President Trump; Mr. Trump framed it as cognitive test for a supposedly senile Mr. Biden," write Glenn Thrush and Sydney Ember. "One of them passed." https://t.co/cNFPJkQxHt

text: As the person in charge of carrying out a free, fair presidential election in a key swing state, Secretary of State Frank LaRose of Ohio is bracing for a level of chaos he never expected. https://t.co/lBf02XXCWZ

text: The Diocese of Rockville Centre on Long Island filed for bankruptcy after facing more than 200 abuse lawsuits. It’s the largest U.S. diocese to do so. https://t.co/66jbJpAuQt

name: nytimes
text: Pope Francis declined to see Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, who is demanding a harder Vatican line on China. The Holy See said meeting just before a U.S. election would be inappropriate. https://t.co/wLGLATDZBS

text: How do you secure an absentee ballot? When will Americans know who has won the presidency? On today's episode of "The Daily" podcast, take a walk through the rules, realities and rancor of the 2020 election. https://t.co/NbmT8NvZCT

text: Russians were urged to return to normal life. But President Vladimir Putin inhabits a virus-free bubble, rarely leaving home. The few people he meets must quarantine first. https://t.co/MUQksaa0y2

text: A court in India has acquitted all the suspects, including several high-profile politicians from Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s party, who were accused of demolishing a centuries-old mosque in Ayodhya in 1992. https://t.co/Mmi4Z51h2j

name: nytimes
text:
After two years without a formal government, a fragile coalition government took power in Belgium on Thursday. The partnership between seven political parties ends one of the longest political stalemates in the Western world.
https://t.co/L8XBwegEFo

name: nytimes
text:
Judge Amy Coney Barrett, President Trump’s nominee to the Supreme Court, signed a newspaper ad in 2006 that supported overturning Roe v. Wade. Her opposition to Roe is in line with Trump’s pledge to appoint justices who would overturn the ruling. 
https://t.co/QPIjnwU8Fv

name: nytimes
text: H&M announced that it would close 250 stores globally next year as part of its plans to consolidate stores and ramp up digital offerings to meet the needs of customers who are increasingly choosing to shop online. https://t.co/n8Xvq5wvVs

name: nytimes
text: The mayor of Moscow ordered companies to send home 30 percent of their workers — and anybody older than 65 or with an underlying condition — after the number of virus cases in the capital doubled over the past week. https://t.co/CG7Tr3GjOM
